context: the patient is a 53-year-old male who was seen for evaluation at the request of dr. x regarding recurrent jaw pain.
this patient has been having what he described as numbness and tingling along the jaw, teeth, and tongue.
he had been diagnosed with a throat infection about a week ago and is finishing a course of avelox at this time.

he has had a loss of sensation of taste as well.

he has had no trauma to the face. he does note a history of headaches.
he has a history of anxiety disorder as well.
he has tried to eliminate his amount of tobacco and he is actually taking nicorette gum at this time.
past surgical history: pertinent for hernia repair.
family history: pertinent for hypertension.
current medications: tylenol.

social history: the patient is single, self-employed carpenter. he chews tobacco or having chewing tobacco for 30 years, about half a can per day, but notes he has been recently off, and he does note occasional moderate alcohol use.
general: the patient is an alert, cooperative, obese, 53-year-old male with a normal-sounding voice and good memory.
neurologic: he does have slightly decreased sensation to the left jaw.
nasal: reveals a deviated nasal septum to the left, moderate, clear drainage, and no erythema.

impression: 1. persistent paresthesia of the left manual teeth and tongue, consider possible neoplasm within the mandible.
impression: 3. hypogeusia with loss of taste.
